stream_context.summary: Kaze spends most of the stream polishing the visual look of the overworld’s volcanic-island section, experimenting with rock shaders, grass transitions and Fast64 UV fixes, while also discussing the first beta test of Course 4 and other overall project milestones.

development_findings.summary: The in-house sound engine has been fully rewritten, letting Kaze start importing new sound effects from Badub (e.g., propeller and windmill loops) across the game.
development_findings.quote: Now that the sound engine is completely remade, we can add some sound effects everywhere.

development_findings.summary: Current focus is visual polish: blending grass into volcanic cliffs, choosing new rock textures, and fixing UVs in Fast64 to make the overworld’s ‘middle island’ look cohesive and ‘more Yoshi’.
Fast64 still contains a lighting/shader bug (yellow-red tint and lighthouse issue); Kaze is waiting on the tool’s maintainers before he can finish certain areas.
development_findings.quote: We really need this Fast64 bug fixed... I was just told to do something different.

development_findings.summary: First external beta test of Course 4 is complete; feedback was better than expected but revealed a soft-lock bug and a weak ‘plane mission’.
development_findings.quote: The testers liked it more than I thought they would… but I kept getting soft-locked and the plane mission sucks.

development_findings.summary: Kaze and Biobak have begun redesigning that plane mission to ‘damage-control’ the problem while keeping the course structure.
A public Google-sheet progress tracker is now online; most courses are 90-100 % finished, while Course 4 is marked 25 % into its beta cycle.
development_findings.quote: If you guys really want, I did this yesterday… you can see how far along the game is.

development_findings.summary: Final ROM is expected to run on EverDrive/OverDrive flashcarts; current crashes will be investigated before release.
development_findings.quote: The final build should work on OverDrive. I do plan on figuring out why the OverDrive crashes.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is considering anti-bootleg measures; flashable ROMs risk creating grey-market cartridges and Nintendo legal heat.
development_findings.quote: If I let people make flashable ROMs… people are going to make bootlegs of my game and sell them.

context_findings.summary: Kaze feels ‘free’ after several busy days and is visibly energized to return to development.
context_findings.quote: I feel like I finally have my freedom back.

context_findings.summary: He dislikes making YouTube videos but does so for reliable income, acknowledging it steals dev time.
context_findings.quote: Do I like making videos? No, I hate making videos. But it’s good money.

context_findings.summary: Release-date questions frustrate him; the new progress tracker is meant to deflect repetitive inquiries.
context_findings.quote: With the mass of people asking that question, it is extremely annoying.

context_findings.summary: Kaze embraces a hardware-limited design philosophy, claiming modern hardware upgrades are ‘expensive garbage’ and that deeper exploration of one console yields better games.
context_findings.quote: Can we just stop and explore one hardware? We’re gonna get better games, cheaper games.

biobak.summary: Handles large-scale graphics passes (‘Biobak reworks’); upcoming work will update textures and may include minor gameplay tweaks but is ‘simple to accommodate’.
biobak.quote: Biobak rework is just him updating the graphics… he does make some gameplay changes, but they are all very simple to accommodate.

biobak.summary: Collaborating with Kaze to redesign Course 4’s troubled plane mission.

badub.summary: Provided new sound effects now being integrated thanks to the rewritten sound engine.
badub.quote: I recently started importing some of Badub’s sound effects.

key_stories.title: Course 4 Beta Wake-Up Call
key_stories.summary: Kaze shipped the first external build of Course 4. Testers were surprisingly positive, but a repeatable soft-lock and a dull plane mission emerged.
key_stories.challenge: Validate whether the newly built Course 4 was fun and stable.
key_stories.process: Sent build to testers, gathered feedback, reviewed soft-lock logs and mission critiques with Biobak.
key_stories.outcome: Overall design approved; bug logged; plane mission slated for redesign.
key_stories.key_quote: We finally got the first beta test for Course 4… the course is on the right track, but the plane mission sucks.

key_stories.title: Spreadsheet Against the Release-Date Question
key_stories.summary: Fed up with constant ‘When will it release?’ queries, Kaze built a public progress tracker showing percentage completion of every course.
key_stories.challenge: Relentless community pressure for a release date.
key_stories.process: Created and shared a Google Sheet, plans to tweet updates regularly.
key_stories.outcome: Community can monitor progress; Kaze hopes to reduce repetitive questions.
key_stories.key_quote: I put out an RTYI progress tracker… it should give you a pretty good idea of how far we are.

key_stories.title: A New Sound Engine Breaths Life
key_stories.summary: An engine rewrite made it possible to layer richer environmental SFX; Kaze demonstrates subtle propeller and windmill loops that ‘make it feel alive’.
key_stories.challenge: Legacy audio system limited the amount and quality of in-game sounds.
key_stories.process: Rewrote audio codebase, coordinated with Badub to import fresh samples.
key_stories.outcome: Dynamic ambience in levels; groundwork laid for full soundtrack and SFX pass.
key_stories.key_quote: Now that the sound engine is completely remade, we can add some sound effects everywhere.

open_questions.context: Kaze announced it is ‘completely remade’ but offered no technical or creative detail.

questions: How do frequent art passes impact schedule and memory budgets?
